list.name: Changes
list.comment: Planning on adding CBO and DIT for extra modularity and maintainability calculations, so added some comments to indicate intention

task.summary: Default task
Tweaks to FileParser
Added test for line count in Main.
Added test for line count in Main.
Renamed the parse function.
Fixed a good amount of bugs with the parser. Statements are now all properly parsed.
My relationship with regex is one of hate and toxic abuse
Tweaks and some bug fixes.
Tweaks and some bug fixes.
More tweaks, lol
Pretty much completed the file parser, and data container classes for ParsedClass and ParsedRepository.
Correction: NOW pretty much complete. I missed a nullpointer issue.
"sPEciFy CoMmIt MesSaGE"
Improved some class detection regexes
Improved some class detection regexes
JavaSourceFileParser is DONE
JavaSourceFileParser is DONE (2)
Small tweaks to the code, and bug fixes. Regex patterns now compile, and classes referenced as variables are now detectable.
No more self-referrals. When adding the signature of a class or object being referenced to a ParsedClass, we now check if the signature is the same as the current class.
Using proper Path class instead of strings. Will make input handling a lot more reliable.
Files and file paths are properly read, and repositories can now be built and populated. Now the actual application work can begin!
Added some overloads for path types (String or Path now works, and inputting a String will format it as well!)
Same as last commit, but this time for File Parser as well as Repo Parser.
- Fixed a few rogue while loops that were caused by regex matcher instantiation. - Fixed order at which regexes will be checked for code statements.
- Added JLS! - Fixed a HUGE, dumb bug relating to pointers for the repo variable in JavaRepositoryParser.
- Added LSEC!
- Improved LSEC!
- Added NVLOC. I got mixed up with the names, LSEC was never added.
Refactor and LSEC getting started.
LSEC's logic is done, now I need to generate a CSV.
LSEC and JLS should, theoretically, have CSV outputs now. God help me

Added some prelimenary groundwork for docstring detection. Eventually I will want to assign docstrings to their methods, but for now all it does is count the number of lines of docstrings there are in a given source file.

Huge improvements to the codebase.
I've switched the data structure of code representation to a proper tree, allowing for an accurate cyclomatic complexity algorithm and for much simpler parsing and inheritance/scope detection, and eventually parsing methods and functions if required.
I've hugely improved comment detection and line counting, making it so that docstrings can now be properly included in the number of lines of comments.
'JavaSourceFileParser' was bloated and hard to read, so I've gutted it and gave its functionality to its subclasses. Especially now that we have a tree, parsing no longer needs to be linear, but rather it is now dynamically programmed through recursive node calls in 'ParsedClass' and 'CodeTree' constructors.
I've also allocated all regex calls to the StringParser class and just in general made things more modular. Huge quality of life improvement for myself with just that.
Add getters for most directly and indirectly referenced classes of a repo.

More big strides; added new features, and fixed bugs or improved existing ones.
- CLASS REFERENCES : Now able to get the most referenced class overall, and now 'most referenced' classes will only be in the repository queried. Otherwise, it always returns 'String', lol.
- REFERENCE DETECTION : Hugely improved detection of classes in source code, now including references hidden in collections such as <T> or List<Integer>.
- PRINT METHODS : You can now print out a file's parsed source code, or a class' parsed source code. Very useful for debugging, and was fun to implement.
- CYCLOMATIC COMPLEXITY : I still need to improve it somewhat, but for now approximation of complexity is fairly close to calculations made by CKJM. I've removed counts for boolean expressions, and also moved most of the detection to 'StringParser' (except for switch statements).
Fixed a index out of bounds error thrown by package name detection. Started adding a way to replace variable names with generic values.
Ok, now the error is ACTUALLY fixed!
Fixed up the class signature lookups in import statements, which means also fixed up counting of indirect references. The parser is basically feature complete for most of our purposes!
Casting a ParsedClass to String spits out the class' signature (rather than its full CodeTree reconstruction)

Scraped removal of var names. Would've increased fidelity, but not worth the effort; detecting variable names on instantiation is easy, but then figuring out where they're called exactly in the code and when to replace them with a generic name is a huge pain.

Scraped removal of var names; detecting attributes will be painful, so I've opted to use a library for LCOM (Lack of Cohesion Metric). Jasome looks promising... and achieves already most of what I have here.

Managed to add variable detection and attribute detection, as well as parsing methods. Still no dependencies, though I almost used "JavaParser" and "Jasome"! Truth be told I tried to look at the library's source code and couldn't understand how it read the inputted data, and how to read metrics from them directly.
I rather work like a mule and build my own solution, but know exactly what my code does and not have to worry about compilation headaches.
Added LCOM1 and LCOM2 calculations in ParsedClass! Was a lot of work, and still needs testing.
Added LCOM calculations to be made over entire repositories. Added WMC metric, aka Weighted Methods per Class, to both ParsedClass and ParsedRepository.
Planning on adding CBO and DIT for extra modularity and maintainability calculations, so added some comments to indicate intention

MESSAGE.value: - Fixed a few rogue while loops that were caused by regex matcher instantiation. - Fixed order at which regexes will be checked for code statements.
- Added JLS! - Fixed a HUGE, dumb bug relating to pointers for the repo variable in JavaRepositoryParser.
- Added LSEC!
- Improved LSEC!
- Added NVLOC. I got mixed up with the names, LSEC was never added.
Refactor and LSEC getting started.
LSEC's logic is done, now I need to generate a CSV.
LSEC and JLS should, theoretically, have CSV outputs now. God help me

Added some prelimenary groundwork for docstring detection. Eventually I will want to assign docstrings to their methods, but for now all it does is count the number of lines of docstrings there are in a given source file.

Huge improvements to the codebase.
I've switched the data structure of code representation to a proper tree, allowing for an accurate cyclomatic complexity algorithm and for much simpler parsing and inheritance/scope detection, and eventually parsing methods and functions if required.
I've hugely improved comment detection and line counting, making it so that docstrings can now be properly included in the number of lines of comments.
'JavaSourceFileParser' was bloated and hard to read, so I've gutted it and gave its functionality to its subclasses. Especially now that we have a tree, parsing no longer needs to be linear, but rather it is now dynamically programmed through recursive node calls in 'ParsedClass' and 'CodeTree' constructors.
I've also allocated all regex calls to the StringParser class and just in general made things more modular. Huge quality of life improvement for myself with just that.

- CYCLOMATIC COMPLEXITY : I still need to improve it somewhat, but for now approximation of complexity is fairly close to calculations made by CKJM. I've removed counts for boolean expressions, and also moved most of the detection to 'StringParser' (except for switch statements).

Fixed up the class signature lookups in import statements, which means also fixed up counting of indirect references. The parser is basically feature complete for most of our purposes!
Casting a ParsedClass to String spits out the class' signature (rather than its full CodeTree reconstruction)

Scraped removal of var names. Would've increased fidelity, but not worth the effort; detecting variable names on instantiation is easy, but then figuring out where they're called exactly in the code and when to replace them with a generic name is a huge pain.

Scraped removal of var names; detecting attributes will be painful, so I've opted to use a library for LCOM (Lack of Cohesion Metric). Jasome looks promising... and achieves already most of what I have here.

I rather work like a mule and build my own solution, but know exactly what my code does and not have to worry about compilation headaches.
